results.title: Thumbelina
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Don Bluth, Gary Goldman and John Pomeroy
results.brief_description: Hans Christian Andersen’s classic fairy tale tells the story of a tiny girl called Thumbelina. One magical night she meets Prince Cornelius, an enchanted fairy as tiny as herself, and she is sure she has found true love. Before their romance can blossom, she is kidnapped by a show business family of toads, waylaid by a scheming beetle and betrothed to a befuddled mole. Thumbelina’s journey home is fraught with adventure, but at last she comes to believe that if she follows her heart, nothing is impossible. Music by Barry Manilow. Features the voices of Jodie Benson, Carole Channing and John Hurt.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Warner Bros Pictures, Don Bluth, Gary Goldman and John Pomeroy

results.title: Thumbelina
results.creator_credit: Primrose Productions, BBC-TV and Lotte Reiniger
results.brief_description: Hans Christian Anderson’s fairy tale retold in animated silhouettes. Lotte Reiniger developed this technique in Germany in the 1920’s and produced several silhouette films in the 1950’s for BBC Television. Designed and animated by Lotte Reiniger.

results.title: Thru the mirror (K)
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney Educational Media Company and Walt Disney
results.brief_description: Mickey Mouse falls asleep reading Lewis Carroll’s ‘Alice Through the Looking Glass’ and dreams himself into wonderland. Features Mickey in 1930’s dance routine. Notable for virtuoso Disney animation techniques, anticipating the design and devices used in the later feature version of Alice in Wonderland.

results.title: Thrown away
results.brief_description:
A man contemplates suicide in a public lavatory cubicle. An unseen figure enters the space and proceeds to carry out the exact sequence ofevents that have bought the man to this critical moment. Is somebody playing a trick on him, or is this his doppelganger? Alarm turns to curiosity and he decides to investigate.
Written, directed and edited by Dan Thomas and featuring Christopher Hatherall as the man.

results.title: Throwing in baseball
results.brief_description: Shows the ins and outs of throwing a baseball following all the procedures of how to “throw” with technique and practice. Takes the viewer through “throwing practice” with its secrets on pitching the “perfect curve ball”.

results.title: Throw Momma from the train
results.creator_credit: Orion Pictures Corporation, Larry Brezner and Danny DeVito
results.brief_description: Larry Donner (Billy Crystal) is not happy. His ex-wife has stolen his novel, reaping the financial rewards and giving Larry a serious case of writer’s block. To complicate matters Owen (Danny De Vito), a student in Larry’s creative writing class wants to participate in a murder-swap; Larry’s wife for Owen’s mother. This eventuates after Larry recommends Owen sees Hitchcock’s ‘Strangers on a train’ to assist in his writing. Owen misinterprets his intentions, taking the film literally. It seems like a simple task but killing Momma isn’t that easy! Written by Stu Silver.

results.title: Through the wire
results.brief_description: In 2002, in amongst raging protests and police reinforcements, more than 40 refugees, rendered desperate by manditory detention, escaped from Woomera Detention Centre in South Australia. Narrated by escaped refugee DJ Moopsie, with powerful music by Mark Daniel, ‘Through the wire’ captures the heightened emotions, despair and desperation of the day and takes us inside the minds of those imprisoned trying to seek a better life.

results.title: Through the rip

results.brief_description: Traces the long and colourful history of the pilot service operating through The Rip at the entrance of Port Phillip Bay. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: Through the olive trees
results.creator_credit: Abbas Kiarostami Prod, Farabi Cinema Foundation and Abbas Kiarostami
results.brief_description: Iranian cinema in the last two decades of the twentieth century has proved to be one of few national cinemas offering an alternative to the dominance of Hollywood, both in terms of production and in terms of aesthetics. Kiarostami is one of the leading directors of post-revolutionary Iranian cinema and his work is intimately concerned with both the nature of human relationships and the power of cinema to influence and transform life. A film crew arrives in a small town devastated by a recent earthquake. Hossein, a young and homeless bricklayer is given a small role as a newly wed husband. The woman who is to play his wife is Tahereh, the girl he adores but who refuses to have anything to do with him. As the director attempts to get the two young people to play their roles in the script, Tahereh and Hossein enact their own drama and conflict in front of the camera. From this simple material, Kiarostami explores the tensions between men and women, reality and imagination, film and politics, and allows us as an audience to explore the ability of film as an art to seduce us even when it is lying to us. Without the use of special effects, big budgets or imaginary beings, “Through the Olive Trees” transports us to a magical world of human drama that Hollywood could not possibly emulate, no matter how much money or technology lies at its disposal.
